Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: LSC Center for Coatings Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
The detections of gravitational waves from coalescing black holes in 2015 launched the field of gravitational wave astronomy. The NSF-funded “A+” upgrade to Advanced LIGO is designed to achieve an order of magnitude increase in detection rate for black hole coalescences, and enable detection of fainter objects like binary neutron stars, greatly increasing their value for multi-messenger astronomy. The A+ upgrade and all 3rd generation detector designs depend on the development of mirrors with low coating thermal noise. The coating thermal noise is reduced, primarily, by lowering the mechanical (elastic) loss of the mirror materials. The core research focus of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC) Center for Coatings Research (CCR) is the development of mirror coatings with low mechanical and optical losses for use in A+ and 3rd generation detectors. The research mission of the CCR includes: understanding and reducing mechanical loss in amorphous metal-oxides, the most widely-used materials in mirror coatings; and developing and testing crystalline (AlGaAs) coatings, which have demonstrated low losses for small mirrors. On a longer time-scale, the CCR is developing mirrors compatible with the proposed 3G detectors’ cryogenic operation.

The residual noise visible in the time-domain gravitational waveforms of black hole mergers first recorded by Advanced LIGO is mostly due to quantum noise of the light and thermal noise due to the mirror coatings. Since that first discovery much progress has been made in reducing quantum noise and the coupling from seismic, scatter and jitter noise, leaving coating thermal noise as the dominant barrier limiting gravitational-wave astronomy in the most sensitive observation band. Reducing this noise source for future generations of detectors requires reducing the mechanical dissipation in the mirror coatings on the test masses, and forms the main goal of the CCR. The CCR combines groups working on computational modeling, coating deposition, and characterization of atomic structure and macroscopic material properties. These components are often performed by four diverse communities that work in relative isolation from each other. The strength of the CCR and its promise of accelerating discoveries arises from close integration of these communities focused on a unified research goal. In its first two years of operation, research in the CCR has identified different structural motifs associated with room-temperature vs cryogenic mechanical losses, which led to synthesis of germania (GeO2) films giving rise to the lowest-loss amorphous oxide film other than silica. Going forward, this structural guide will serve as a paradigm informing the development of high-refractive index amorphous coatings with lower elastic loss. In addition, thermo-optically-optimized AlGaAs crystalline coatings have demonstrated a coating thermal noise well below the requirements for A+, and the CCR has generated a development schedule to scale up these coatings to LIGO mirror sizes and will continue investigations into these materials. Other research paths include: exploring deposition techniques to produce “ultrastable glasses” using amorphous metal-oxides; and stabilizing amorphous coatings against crystallization in order to allow elastic loss reduction via high temperature annealing either with nano-layering or with different doping materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The LIGO Scientific Collaboration Center for Coatings Research (CCR) is a collaborative project spanning eight institutions and co-funded by the NSF and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. Over the course of this three-year award the CCR made significant strides in addressing thermal noise in interferometer mirrors, a critical barrier in enhancing the sensitivity of LIGO's future iterations. Our research has included: the development of Ti:GeO2 coatings that have the potential to meet the thermal noise requirements for Advanced LIGO +, the development of other amorphous coatings such as hydrogenated amorphous Silicon that show promise for implementation in future detectors, expanding our understanding of the atomic-level mechanisms responsible for mechanical loss which is directly related to thermal noise, and progressing the development of AlGaAs crystalline coatings.

At Berkeley, work centered on studies of amorphous silicon (with added H and/or C), tantala, and simple oxides (silica and alumina), all either current or potential future mirror coatings. Hydrogenated amorphous silicon has shown a remarkable result: ultra-low optical absorption, below 3 ppm for quarter-wavelength thick films at 2000 nm, reduced by many orders of magnitude from unhydrogenated silicon, allowing the fabrication of silicon-based cryogenic detectors. The mechanical loss of amorphous silicon also reduced after hydrogenation suggesting that hydrogenation is a good strategy for development of a new generation of cryogenic gravitational wave detectors. Absorption at 1064 nm, used in current room temperature detectors, also showed many orders of magnitude reduced absorption, potentially enabling its use in multimaterial coatings of near-term detectors.  

 

Adding Carbon to amorphous Si seemed initially promising, as transparency in visible light notably increased, indicating an increased band gap as hoped for, but mechanical loss and optical absorption were nonetheless increased instead of decreased; future experiments will focus on a growth technique that increases the ratio of sp3/sp2 bonding such as used in industrial applications for tetrahedral amorphous C.  

 

Amorphous tantala showed improvements in both mechanical loss and index of refraction on increasing growth temperature and tuning of the incident energy adatoms. Tantala films grown with lower energy adatoms or at higher growth temperature have lower room temperature mechanical loss and higher refractive index, thus an improved figure of merit for mirror coatings, correlated with changes to the ratio of corner- versus edge- and face-sharing polyhedra as theoretically predicted by others in CCR. 

 

With the study of simple oxides, we wanted to obtain deeper insight into the theories and hypotheses of the role of ultrastable glasses, particularly their connection to lower mechanical loss and hence lower thermal noise, and the means to obtain these.  Increasing growth temperature for both alumina and silica led to increased atomic density and elastic properties, and reduced mechanical noise, as for amorphous silicon, but by less than an order of magnitude, unlike the large changes for amorphous silicon.  For silica, it is now clear that it cannot be grown in the ultrastable state, and we hypothesize that this is because it is a strong glass former, unlike silicon. The case of alumina is more complex, as it is supposed to be a more fragile glass than silica, hence potentially more like silicon. Experiments are still underway; the reduction in mechanical loss at growth temperatures near 0.8 Tg was not as large as expected, but Tg is not well known.  In addition to completing our studies of alumina, we will next study simple oxide glasses with variable fragility to understand whether a threshold for ultrastability exists. 


The strength of the CCR and its promise of accelerating discoveries arises from continuing the close integration of our research groups and working together with the LIGO-labs at Caltech and MIT, and wider LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA collaboration.  The broader impact of our research lies in enabling upgrades to LIGO that have lower coating thermal noise that advances our understanding of the universe through new discoveries in gravitational wave astronomy, as well as contributing valuable insights into fundamental materials physics and precision optics.
